hillbillies.part3.facade

Interface IFacade

  • All Superinterfaces:
    IFacade

    public interface IFacade
extends IFacade
    Implement this interface to connect your code to the graphical user interface (GUI).
    • For separating the code that you wrote from the code that was provided to you, put ALL your code in the src folder. The code that is provided to you stays in the src-provided folder. Only if you modify the provided code, it's advised to move the modified code to the src folder, so that your changes cannot be accidentally overwritten by an updated version of the provided code.
    • You should at least create the following classes in the package hillbillies.model:
      • a class Unit for representing a Hillbilly Unit
      • a class World for representing a Hillbilly World
      • a class Faction for representing a unit faction
      • a class Boulder for representing a boulder object
      • a class Log for representing a log object
      • a class Task for representing a task program
      You may, of course, add additional classes as you see fit.
    • You should create a class Facade that implements this interface. This class should be placed in the package hillbillies.part3.facade in your src folder.
    • The header of that Facade class should look as follows:
      public class Facade implements IFacade { ... }
      Consult the Java tutorial for more information on interfaces, if necessary.
    • Your Facade class should offer a default constructor.
    • Each non-deprecated method defined in this IFacade interface and the interfaces from part 1 (@link hillbillies.part1.facade.IFacade) and part 2 ( IFacade) must be implemented by your @{link Facade} class. For example, the implementation of IFacade.getCubeCoordinate(Unit) should call one or more methods on the given unit to retrieve its current cube coordinate.
    • The methods IFacade.advanceTime(Unit, double) and IFacade.work(Unit) from part 1 are deprecated and no longer need to be implemented.
    • Methods in this interface are only allowed to throw exceptions of type ModelException (this class is provided). No other exception types are allowed. This exception can only be thrown if (1) calling a method of your Unit class with the given parameters would violate a precondition, or (2) if the method of your Unit class throws an exception (if so, wrap the exception in the ModelException).
    • ModelException should not be used anywhere outside of your Facade implementation.
    • Your Facade implementation should only contain trivial code (for example, calling a method, combining multiple return values into an array, creating @Value instances, catching exceptions and wrapping it in a ModelException). All non-trivial code should be placed in the other classes that you create.
    • The rules described above and the documentation described below for each method apply only to your Facade class. Your other classes (e.g., Unit, World) should follow the rules described in the assignment.
    • Do not modify the signatures of the methods defined in this interface.

    • Method Detail

      • createTaskFactory

        ITaskFactory<?,?,Task> createTaskFactory()
        Create a new instance of a Task factory.

        This factory is used by the parser (TaskParser) to construct an in-memory representation of your program. For example, when reading the task description 

         name: "test"
 priority: 1
 activities: moveTo here;
        the parser will create a Task object by (conceptually) executing the following code: 
         factory.createTask("test", 1, factory.createMoveTo(factory.createHerePosition()))
        on the returned factory object.

        For testing, you may use the methods from TaskParser yourself, as demonstrated in the partial test file Part3TestPartial.

        Returns:
        An instance of ITaskFactory. See the documentation of that interface for an explanation of its parameters.

      • isWellFormed

        boolean isWellFormed(Task task)
              throws ModelException
        Returns whether the given task is well-formed. A task is well-formed if
        • it is type-safe
        • there are no break statements outside loops
        • variables assigned before they are first used
        See the assignment text for more details.
        Parameters:
        task - The task to check for well-formedness
        Throws:
        ModelException - A precondition was violated or an exception was thrown.
        Note:
        Single-student groups may always return true for this method.

      • areTasksPartOf

        boolean areTasksPartOf(Scheduler scheduler,
                       java.util.Collection<Task> tasks)
                throws ModelException
        Returns whether the given tasks are all part of the given scheduler.
        Parameters:
        scheduler - The scheduler on which to check
        tasks - The tasks to check
        Returns:
        true if all given tasks are part of the scheduler; false otherwise.
        Throws:
        ModelException - A precondition was violated or an exception was thrown.

      • getAllTasksIterator

        java.util.Iterator<Task> getAllTasksIterator(Scheduler scheduler)
                                      throws ModelException
        Returns an iterator for all tasks currently managed by the given scheduler.
        Parameters:
        scheduler - The scheduler for which to return an iterator.
        Returns:
        An iterator that yields all scheduled tasks managed by the given scheduler, independent of whether they're currently assigned to a Unit or not. Completed tasks should not be part of the result. The tasks should be delivered by decreasing priority (highest priority first).
        Throws:
        ModelException - A precondition was violated or an exception was thrown.

      • getSchedulersForTask

        java.util.Set<Scheduler> getSchedulersForTask(Task task)
                                       throws ModelException
        Return all schedulers in which the given task is present.
        Parameters:
        task - The task for which to retrieve the schedulers
        Returns:
        A set of all schedulers that contain the given task.
        Throws:
        ModelException - A precondition was violated or an exception was thrown.

      • getAssignedUnit

        Unit getAssignedUnit(Task task)
              throws ModelException
        Return the unit currently assigned to the given task, if any.
        Parameters:
        task - The task for which to retrieve the unit
        Returns:
        The unit that is currently assigned to the given task, or null if the task is not assigned to a unit.
        Throws:
        ModelException - A precondition was violated or an exception was thrown.
